subTopics.title: Genes and cells involved in VDJ recombionation

quizzes.question: Identify the protein complex directly responsible for initiating VDJ recombination by recognizing and cleaving specific DNA sequences flanking the V, D, and J gene segments in developing lymphocytes.
quizzes.goodAnswer: The RAG complex, composed of RAG1 and RAG2 proteins, initiates VDJ recombination by recognizing recombination signal sequences (RSSs) and catalyzing DNA cleavage at conserved heptamer sequences.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: The Artemis-DNA-PKcs complex initiates VDJ recombination by recognizing coding joints and catalyzing hairpin opening during the process of gene rearrangement in developing lymphocytes at the coding ends.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: The TdT enzyme initiates VDJ recombination by recognizing recombination signal sequences (RSSs) and adding N-nucleotides at the junctions of V, D, and J gene segments in developing lymphocytes during junctional diversification.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: DNA Ligase IV complex initiates VDJ recombination by recognizing broken DNA ends and ligating the gene segments after RAG-mediated cleavage in developing lymphocytes within the coding regions.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: The Ku70/Ku80 heterodimer initiates VDJ recombination by recognizing DNA double-strand breaks and recruiting DNA-PKcs to facilitate hairpin opening during gene rearrangement in developing lymphocytes at the RSS sites.

quizzes.question: During VDJ recombination of the immunoglobulin heavy chain locus, which of the following sequences accurately represents the ordered joining of gene segments?
quizzes.goodAnswer: DH -> JH joining is followed by VH -> DJH joining, establishing the complete variable region exon in developing B lymphocytes within the bone marrow.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: VH -> DH joining is followed by JH -> VHDJ joining, establishing the complete variable region exon in developing T lymphocytes within the thymus.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: VH -> JH joining is followed by DH -> VHJD joining, establishing the complete variable region exon in developing B lymphocytes within the thymus.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: DH -> VH joining is followed by JH -> DHVJ joining, establishing the complete variable region exon in developing T lymphocytes within the bone marrow.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: JH -> DH joining is followed by VH -> JHDV joining, establishing the complete variable region exon in developing B lymphocytes within the lymph nodes.

quizzes.question: Which of the following enzymes is primarily responsible for the addition of P-nucleotides at the hairpin-opened coding ends during VDJ recombination, contributing to junctional diversity?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Artemis, in complex with DNA-PKcs, is responsible for opening DNA hairpins generated by RAG complex, and subsequent processing can lead to the addition of palindromic P-nucleotides at coding junctions.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is responsible for opening DNA hairpins and adding template-independent N-nucleotides at the junctions of V, D, and J gene segments, creating palindromic sequences.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: DNA polymerase lambda is responsible for opening DNA hairpins and adding non-templated P-nucleotides at the junctions of V, D, and J gene segments, generating palindromic insertions.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID) is responsible for opening DNA hairpins and adding somatic hypermutation-derived P-nucleotides at the junctions of V, D, and J gene segments during recombination.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: DNA Ligase IV is responsible for opening DNA hairpins and adding ligated P-nucleotides at the junctions of V, D, and J gene segments, contributing to palindromic sequences.

quizzes.question: Identify the primary cell types in which VDJ recombination of immunoglobulin and T-cell receptor genes occurs, leading to the generation of diverse antigen receptors.
quizzes.goodAnswer: VDJ recombination primarily occurs in developing B lymphocytes within the bone marrow and developing T lymphocytes within the thymus, generating diverse immunoglobulin and TCR repertoires.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: VDJ recombination primarily occurs in mature B lymphocytes within the lymph nodes and mature T lymphocytes within the spleen, generating diverse immunoglobulin and TCR repertoires after antigen encounter.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: VDJ recombination primarily occurs in plasma cells within the bone marrow and cytotoxic T lymphocytes within the peripheral blood, generating diverse antibody and TCR repertoires during effector responses.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: VDJ recombination primarily occurs in hematopoietic stem cells within the bone marrow and thymic epithelial cells within the thymus, generating diverse immunoglobulin and TCR repertoires during hematopoiesis.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: VDJ recombination primarily occurs in dendritic cells within the lymph nodes and macrophages within the spleen, generating diverse antigen presentation molecules and TCR repertoires for immune surveillance.

quizzes.question: Determine the critical enzyme responsible for initiating isotype switching in activated B lymphocytes by introducing DNA breaks within the switch (S) regions located upstream of heavy chain constant region genes.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID) is the enzyme responsible for initiating isotype switching by deaminating cytosine residues in the switch (S) regions, leading to DNA breaks and class switch recombination.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is the enzyme responsible for initiating isotype switching by adding N-nucleotides at the junctions during class switch recombination in activated B lymphocytes within germinal centers.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: RAG recombinase is the enzyme responsible for initiating isotype switching by mediating VDJ recombination and the subsequent class switch recombination in activated B lymphocytes upon antigen stimulation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: DNA Ligase IV is the enzyme responsible for initiating isotype switching by ligating the DNA ends after the deletion of intervening constant region genes during class switch recombination in activated B lymphocytes.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Artemis-DNA-PKcs complex is the enzyme responsible for initiating isotype switching by opening DNA hairpins formed during class switch recombination and facilitating the joining of switch regions in activated B lymphocytes.

quizzes.question: Identify the specific DNA sequences, located upstream of each heavy chain constant region gene (except for Cδ), that mediate class switch recombination by serving as targets for AID-induced DNA breaks and subsequent recombination.
quizzes.goodAnswer: Switch (S) regions, composed of repetitive sequences, are located upstream of each heavy chain constant region gene (except Cδ) and mediate class switch recombination by targeting AID and facilitating DNA strand breaks.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Recombination signal sequences (RSSs), composed of conserved heptamer and nonamer sequences, are located upstream of each heavy chain variable region gene and mediate class switch recombination by targeting RAG complex.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Coding joints, formed during VDJ recombination, are located between variable and constant region genes and mediate class switch recombination by targeting DNA Ligase IV for gene segment joining.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Promoter regions, located upstream of each heavy chain constant region gene, are involved in transcriptional regulation and mediate class switch recombination by targeting RNA polymerase for gene expression.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Enhancer sequences, located downstream of each heavy chain constant region gene, are involved in transcriptional activation and mediate class switch recombination by targeting transcription factors for gene upregulation.

quizzes.question: Which of the following cytokines is primarily associated with inducing isotype switching to IgE in B lymphocytes during allergic responses and parasitic infections?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Interleukin-4 (IL-4) is a key cytokine that promotes isotype switching to IgE in B lymphocytes, particularly during allergic reactions and responses to helminth parasites, by signaling through the IL-4 receptor.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) is a key cytokine that promotes isotype switching to IgE in B lymphocytes, particularly during antiviral responses and responses to intracellular bacteria, by signaling through the IFN-γ receptor.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β) is a key cytokine that promotes isotype switching to IgE in B lymphocytes, particularly during immunosuppression and responses to commensal bacteria, by signaling through the TGF-β receptor.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Interleukin-10 (IL-10) is a key cytokine that promotes isotype switching to IgE in B lymphocytes, particularly during resolution of inflammation and responses to fungal infections, by signaling through the IL-10 receptor.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) is a key cytokine that promotes isotype switching to IgE in B lymphocytes, particularly during inflammatory responses and responses to gram-negative bacteria, by signaling through the TNF-α receptor.

quizzes.question: Following isotype switching, what is the primary alteration in the antibody molecule that leads to a change in its effector function while preserving its antigen specificity?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Isotype switching results in the replacement of the heavy chain constant region, altering the antibody's effector function (e.g., complement activation, Fc receptor binding) while maintaining the same variable region and antigen specificity.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Isotype switching results in the replacement of the light chain constant region, altering the antibody's antigen specificity while maintaining the same heavy chain variable region and effector function.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Isotype switching results in the replacement of the heavy chain variable region, altering the antibody's antigen specificity and effector function while maintaining the same constant region.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Isotype switching results in the replacement of the light chain variable region, altering the antibody's effector function while maintaining the same heavy chain constant region and antigen specificity.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Isotype switching results in the replacement of both heavy and light chain variable regions, altering both the antibody's antigen specificity and effector function in conjunction with constant region change.

quizzes.question: Identify the primary function of Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) class I molecules in the adaptive immune response.
quizzes.goodAnswer: MHC class I molecules primarily function to present peptides derived from intracellular pathogens, such as viruses and certain bacteria, to cytotoxic CD8+ T lymphocytes, initiating cell-mediated immunity.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: MHC class I molecules primarily function to present peptides derived from extracellular pathogens, such as bacteria and fungi, to helper CD4+ T lymphocytes, initiating humoral immunity.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: MHC class I molecules primarily function to present lipid antigens to natural killer (NK) cells, activating innate immune responses against infected or transformed cells.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: MHC class I molecules primarily function to present self-antigens to regulatory T lymphocytes, maintaining immune tolerance and preventing autoimmunity in peripheral tissues.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: MHC class I molecules primarily function to present carbohydrate antigens to B lymphocytes, inducing T-independent antibody responses against bacterial polysaccharides.

quizzes.question: Determine the class of Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) molecules predominantly expressed on professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as dendritic cells, macrophages, and B lymphocytes, and involved in presenting antigens to CD4+ T helper cells.
quizzes.goodAnswer: MHC class II molecules are predominantly expressed on professional APCs (dendritic cells, macrophages, B cells) and present peptides derived from extracellular pathogens to CD4+ T helper lymphocytes, initiating adaptive immunity.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: MHC class I molecules are predominantly expressed on professional APCs (dendritic cells, macrophages, B cells) and present peptides derived from intracellular pathogens to CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes, initiating cell-mediated immunity.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: MHC class III molecules are predominantly expressed on professional APCs (dendritic cells, macrophages, B cells) and present complement components and cytokines involved in inflammatory responses and innate immunity.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: MHC class II molecules are predominantly expressed on all nucleated cells and present peptides derived from intracellular pathogens to CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes, initiating antiviral responses.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: MHC class I molecules are predominantly expressed on non-nucleated cells such as erythrocytes and present lipid antigens to natural killer T (NKT) cells, initiating innate-like immune responses.

quizzes.question: Which of the following best describes the source of antigenic peptides presented by MHC class II molecules to CD4+ T helper cells?
quizzes.goodAnswer: MHC class II molecules present peptides derived from extracellular pathogens that are internalized into vesicles by antigen-presenting cells, processed in lysosomes, and loaded onto MHC class II in endosomes.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: MHC class II molecules present peptides derived from intracellular pathogens that are processed in the cytoplasm by the proteasome and transported into the endoplasmic reticulum for loading onto MHC class II molecules.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: MHC class I molecules present peptides derived from extracellular pathogens that are internalized into vesicles by antigen-presenting cells, processed in lysosomes, and loaded onto MHC class I in endosomes.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: MHC class I molecules present peptides derived from intracellular pathogens that are processed in the cytoplasm by the proteasome and transported into the endoplasmic reticulum for loading onto MHC class I molecules within the Golgi apparatus.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: MHC class II molecules present lipid antigens derived from microbial cell walls that are directly loaded onto MHC class II molecules in the endoplasmic reticulum without prior processing in lysosomes or proteasomes.

quizzes.question: Explain the significance of the high degree of polymorphism in MHC genes within a population.
quizzes.goodAnswer: The high polymorphism of MHC genes ensures that a population can respond to a wide array of diverse pathogens, as different MHC alleles bind and present different peptide antigens, increasing population-level immunity.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: The high polymorphism of MHC genes ensures that individuals develop autoimmunity, as diverse MHC alleles can present self-peptides with high affinity, leading to T cell activation and self-tissue damage.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: The high polymorphism of MHC genes ensures that transplantation success rates are increased, as diverse MHC alleles reduce the likelihood of graft rejection due to MHC matching between donor and recipient.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: The high polymorphism of MHC genes ensures that immune responses are uniform across a population, as diverse MHC alleles converge on presenting the same set of conserved pathogen-derived peptides.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: The high polymorphism of MHC genes ensures that vaccine efficacy is enhanced in all individuals, as diverse MHC alleles broaden the range of peptide antigens presented to T cells after vaccination, improving protection.
